Q: How to reduce the size of a file after packaging it as an exe A:
  • copy output: your-app.exe (12 MB) to another Windows 10.
  • execute your-app.exe (only use tkinter)
    • can display GUI Window
    • open a file selection dialog
    • then load a text file, then show in GUI Window

key point is use: python env, then install module in python env.

Q: I want to improve my program thats about a React Tasklist A:

Can you try to get the code formatting to work? It's hard to read the second part. Preferably remove all the comments too, unless you want to ask about something specific in a comment.

Q: Unable to create a web driver object if the selenium container is stuck in the middle of a session A:

You can’t “force” new RemoteWebDriver(...) to succeed if the Selenium Standalone container is single-session and currently hung/busy. When it’s stuck, the HTTP call that creates a new session blocks waiting for the server to respond.

Practical fixes (pick one):

  1. Set timeouts so it fails fast instead of freezing
    Use an HttpClient with connect/read timeouts and pass it to the driver. Then you can catch the timeout and recover (restart container / retry).

    import org.openqa.selenium.remote.RemoteWebDriver;
import org.openqa.selenium.remote.http.ClientConfig;
import org.openqa.selenium.remote.http.HttpClient;

ClientConfig cfg = ClientConfig.defaultConfig()
        .readTimeout(Duration.ofSeconds(30))
        .connectionTimeout(Duration.ofSeconds(10));

HttpClient.Factory factory = HttpClient.Factory.createDefault(cfg);

return new RemoteWebDriver(containerLocator, options, factory);

    (If you’re on Selenium 3, upgrade—Selenium 4 added this cleaner HTTP client config.)

  2. Don’t use a single “standalone” for async jobs — use Selenium Grid / multiple nodes
    selenium/standalone-chrome is effectively one browser at a time. If one session hangs, everyone else queues. For async tasks, run a Grid (hub + multiple chrome nodes) or use Selenoid. Then each task gets an independent session and a hung one won’t block creation for others.

  3. Health-check + kill the stuck session/container before creating a new driver
    Before creating the driver, ping GET /status. If it times out or reports “busy” forever, restart the container (or replace it with an orchestrated service). You can also query /sessions (Grid) to identify sessions and delete them, but Standalone often can’t reliably recover from a wedged chromedriver—restart is the real fix.

  4. Guarantee cleanup (still important)
    Even though you said ignore block 2, your quit() must be in finally, and also add pageLoadTimeout / scriptTimeout so tasks don’t hang indefinitely.

Bottom line: the correct approach is (1) add HTTP timeouts so RemoteWebDriver creation doesn’t freeze, and (2) stop using a single standalone container for concurrent async work—use Grid / multiple containers or restart-on-failure.
